Hi Alan and thanks for the information on Mrs. Schneidman.  I will 
have to=
 look into finding the catalog.  
I just came upon this information today a=
nd it coincides with your 
question.  It is from 'Kodogu' pg. 20, by Gunthe=
r Heckmann

'Until a few years ago it was generally agreed that sword decor=
ations 
of this sort were produced by the Ainu, the native inhabitants of 
=
Japan's northern island Ezo, which is nowadays called Hokkaido.  For 
this =
reason these sort of objects are usually called Ezo koshirae.  
Because of =
the fact that the Ainu did not have a deep knowledge of 
metal processing, =
we should rather use the term Shoki Kinko, 'the 
first kinko period', for t=
his type of work.  Other ideas about the 
origin of these objects can be or=
iented from the beginnings of the 
fire gilding technique in China, during =
the T'ang dynesty (618-906), 
and the possible use of imported Chinese bron=
ze for the production of 
sword decoration.
The basic metal used for these =
objects is different from the metal 
usually used for sword decoration.  An=
 examination of the metal 
content of this pair of menuki was performed in =
April 1996, by Prof. 
Dr. Richter of the Institut fur technologie der Maler=
ei, in 
Stuttgart, using LASER micro spectral analysis and atomic absorptio=
n 
spectral anallysis.   The main componenets of the metal in this 
object =
are 70% copper, 25% silver, and the remaining 5% shows traces 
of lead, gol=
d, mercury iron, calcium magnesium, aluninum, and 
silicon.  The gold and m=
ercury derive from the fire gilding.  The 
other contents can be taced to t=
he partially refined copper.  An 
alloy of 25% silver and 75% copper is oft=
en used for Japanese sword 
decoration and is called oborogin.  With a high=
er percentage of 
silver to copper the alloy is called rogin or more common=
ly 
shibuichi.  For the outome of the alloy, it is important to know that 
=
when silver is added to copper in these quantities, it tends to rise 
to th=
e surface, which is the reason for the silvery appearance of the 
Shoki Kin=
ko pieces.  It is not clear yet why especially this alloy 
was used for swo=
rd decoration at such an early time.  These objects 
are mostly deated from=
 the early to middle Muromachi period (1400 - 
1450), sometimes even earlie=
r.  Shibuichi was always considered to be 
a metal of the Edo period, but t=
he date of origin of oborogin is 
unknown.  Further analyses of the so coal=
led Shoki Kinko decarations 
are necessary before any conclusion can be mad=
e about the components 
of these sword fittings.  With this first analyses =
an important and 
stimulating step was made towards further studies of this=
 subject.

Buttweiler in his writing stated he felt the dark color under th=
e 
gilding may have been due to the effect of mercury on the copper in 
com=
bination with the gold creating a layer of 'shakudo' and this 
effect may h=
ave led t it's discovery as an alloy.  (This gilding was 
post probably don=
e by making a slurry paste of gold filings and 
mercury and then heat evapo=
rating the mercury leaving the gold layer).

Note:  link to picture of Ezo =
fitting used in the book:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/ph=
otos/view/7936?b=3D2



-- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Alan Bale" <ab=
ale@...> wrote:
>
> Regarding Ezo menuki I think that these were not suri-h=
egashi inlay 
but genuinely worn pieces. Something that has puzzled me for =
a long 
time is that many Ezo menuki I have seen have a silvery metal base =

not unlike shibuichi but the books always say 'yamagane',  but I have 
nev=
er seen this silvery metal on anything other than Ezo items.
> Alan
